reviewText: For JUST a taste, try THIS!Just three episodes here.The other, dedicated collections (20 episodes, each)---- check them out ---- are ridiculously expensive:The Rifleman, Boxed Set 1................$210The Rifleman, Boxed Set 2 (Vols. 5-8).$150The Rifleman Boxed Set 3..................$231The Rifleman Box Set Collection 4.......$243The Rifleman Box Set Collection 5.......$225The Rifleman: Boxed Set Collection 6..$280There's some kind of ---- I HATE t-h-i-s word ---- "copyright" problem.All of the Four[movie]Star[s] Productions owners are dead, leaving "ownership"music, residuals, etcetera, up in the air. Want more than three PUBLIC DOMAINepisodes? It'll COST ya!

reviewText: I remember having a crush on Chuck Conners when watching this as a girl.  I still do 40 or more years later.  He is worth watching in all these episodes.  These are nice, clean, old fashioned western episodes with no sex, swearing, excessive gore etc.  I rather like going back to that myself.  And looking at Chuck.
summary: Liked Chuck since I was a girl

reviewText: I loved the Rifleman growing up, like a surrogate father figure.  So I liked having some of the shows to remember simpler times.  It would have been nice to have a few more of the shows for the price, and don't know who selected the three, they are okay but none that I remembered.  Plus the transfer is grainy and lined.  Other than that, it is a nice set.

reviewText: Good guy over Bad, Father and Son Interaction, Good Guy Sheriff all in one package and in perhaps direct contrast to what we may no longer have in reality. Makes one wish for yesteryear when fathers and lawmen could be trusted and depended on because they were real men instead of the ;politically correct' whipped individuals we so often see today.

reviewText: Classic western action at it's finest! Bonanza, Big Valley, and Gunsmoke are other good choices. The thing that makes this show good is the modified rifle/shotgun that can shoot rapid fire rounds despite this taking place in the old west. The opening theme song CLEARLY displays this action. One of my favorite westerns EVER to this day. Tombstone and Young Guns are good modern movies but the Rifleman is an all-time classic. Blast from the past that stands the test of time. 'Nuff said.

reviewText: This three episode collection issued by Alpha Video contains the same three episodes that have been issued by various companies specializing in public domain material; in fact, if you already own any DVDs of the Chuck Connors Western "The Rifleman," be sure to compare the episodes on your discs with those contained on Alpha's so as to avoid possible duplication.  The episodes include "Outlaw's Inheritance," "Day of the Hunter," and "Mail Order Groom."  For casual fans of the series who would like to include a few episodes in their classic TV collection, this DVD will fit the bill nicely.  But serious fans of  "The Rifleman" will want to check out the various official DVD box sets issued by MPI for the best episode selection and best audio/visual quality.Trivia Note:  John Anderson guest stars in two of the episodes, "Day of the Hunter" and "Mail Order Groom."  These two episodes were originally broadcast just a week apart!
